Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: depends on what `string` is.  Is it a char array? so that `string[1]` is the second char in the array?

Author: kalmb#7113

Author: kalmb#7113

Author: kalmb#7113
Content: is there a difference? I thought string name = "aa" was just an array same as char name[]name[0]

Author: kalmb#7113
Content: name[0] a

Author: kalmb#7113
Content: name[1] a

Author: kalmb#7113
Content: name[2] /0

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `string name = "aa";` declares a string literal, which is immutable (it can't be changed because it's not stored in a part of memory that is changeable once the program is running).

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `char name[6] ="abcde";` declares a char array and initializes the values which can be changed later.

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content:
oh dear, this Yale website says here that

http://www.cs.yale.edu/homes/aspnes/pinewiki/C(2f)Pointers.html#Assigning_to_pointer_variables

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: "To initialize a pointer variable, you have to assign to it the address of something that already exists. " (from yale)

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: but I thought that you can declare a pointer variable like this: int *p;

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: and it will reserve memory of the fixed size 4 bytes (because an integer is 4 bytes)

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: i'm really hoping Yale (#3 school in america) is wrong here

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Yale's not wrong.  `int *p;` declares a pointer that you've told it will point to an int.  But it doesn't reserve any space for that int.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
```int num = 5;
int *ptr_to_num = #```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: now `ptr_to_num` is pointing to the variable `num`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: all of this is explained later in the course.

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: ah ok, thanks!

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content:
`Yale's not wrong.  int *p; declares a pointer that you've told it will point to an int.  But it doesn't reserve any space for that int.`  
but it does reserve space for the pointer that I just declared, right?

Author: therewolf#7605
Content: The pointer itself is declared, but it is not initialized

Author: therewolf#7605
Content: So yes, there is space reserved  in which to store an address.

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content:
right, that's my point, if I stop the debugger after the pointer itself is declared (but prior to initializing) that pointer will have an: 
```1) an address given by printf("&p   = %p\n", &p);```
```2) a value given by printf("p  = %d\n", *(int *) &p);```
right?

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: i just wanna make sure I understand what happens during the declaration/initialization process

Author: therewolf#7605
Content: Yes, that all looks correct

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669

Author: LiberaVeritas#1294
Content: You are declaring a string s, but because strings are pointers under the hood, you have to allocate memory before you can use them in your loop. I suggest using a char array instead.

Author: milo yiannopoulos#2669
Content: also you put `s[2] = '\0';` inside the for loop instead of above it (which means that line of code will be executed 26 times rather than 1 time)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: 5x52 minutes??   Yes, there are 5-char passwords and I think that is one of them.

Author: Baris Can Ceylan#4867
Content: just a wild guess, probably I exaggerated. I'll use a timer to check how long it takes to finish all 4 chars.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: fwiw, my version can find a 4-char password in 20 seconds.  But a 5-char one takes about 15 mins.  (given the exponential nature of adding that last char)

Author: Baris Can Ceylan#4867
Content: yes, every added char multiplies the time by 52 (A-Za-z).

Author: Baris Can Ceylan#4867
Content: I used a timer. from 'A' to 'zzzz' , it took about 67 seconds. I guess it is safe to say finding 'ROFL' for example, would take about 20 secs (mine starts with uppercases, then tries lowercases).

Author: Raggy#0001
Content: I'm looking through the man page and it uses the first 7 bits to compute the hash so you should be able to halve the space you have to search through if you don't bother checking the chars that end in 1 or 0

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Rags#3015   the passwords will only be in the ranges of 'a'-'z' and 'A'-'Z'

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: also, it uses the lowest 7 bits, so that would be the entire value.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ie, 'z' is 122 in decimal or  `0b01111010` in binary.  (or `0b1111010` if you only use the lowest 7 bits, which is still 'z')    *edited for binary notation*

Author: dicoding#5977
Content: Hi guys! Can anybody explain me please why comparison of string literal and char array via `==` doesn't work but comparison via `strcmp` works well? üòê

Author: Raggy#0001
Content: @dicoding strings don't exist the same way in C. They exist as char arrays

Author: Raggy#0001
Content: When you try to equate them, it decays to a pointer which doesn't work

Author: Raggy#0001
Content: You need a function that can take those pointers and iterate over the strings until it reaches a null terminator

Author: Raggy#0001
Content: And sees if they match perfectly or not

Author: Raggy#0001
Content: Passing strings and *char[] into function decays them into pointers

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: remember that a string is just a char array ending in 0, so if you have char test array that can hold 6 chars (the 5 letters plus the null char), you can use that for a 1-char string simply by putting the null char in the second position

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: "a" is array[0] = 'a' and array[1] = '\0'

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you have array[6] it can be used to make all of your strings, just by filling in the appropriate slot

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you initialize it with all null chars, then you only have to populate the letters

Author: Sir Fugglepuff#9420
Content:
Hey guys, I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask but i've just come accross this in the crack problem...

what's the difference in doing 
`char *blah = "blah"; `
and
`char blah[] = "blah"`

I've had a look around online.. but I don't really understand

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the first declares a 'string literal' that is stored in read-only memory (so cannot be changed).  the second declares a char array stored on the stack that can hold 5 chars and is initialized to "blah" (plus the null char at the end).  those chars can be changed.

Author: Aternus#9711

Author: Kinno#3002

Author: Kinno#3002
Content: Anyways the way it works

Author: Kinno#3002
Content: Is pointing at the beginning in memory(of the array) + offset

Author: Kinno#3002
Content: So to get the 1st item, you offset by 0

Author: Kinno#3002
Content: Hence arrays starting at 0

Author: meh#5832
Content: If it is C language, it's about dynamic array and static array.  Char *blah while being compiled,  a memory block is allocated to store "blah",  *blah points to the starting point of this memory block.  You could later resize the memory using malloc function.   Char blah[] is static array with static size, while being compiled, a static memory block is assigned to store "blah".  Should you use blah[5], you will get array overflow error

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: There must be some rules about the resizing, right? Otherwise how can the computer gurantee that you'll get a contigious chunk of memory?

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: And what about garbage collection? Are they treated the same?

Author: meh#5832
Content: It's assigned by malloc function.  When you use pointer type, you do your own garbage collection management.  Basically, you need to use free it first, then allocate.  There are few functions for memory allocation, you will need to form the good habit to do your own garbage collection.  Also, when you use pointer type, there won't be array overflow error, you need to remember the size yourself, otherwise the program will take whatever it get as instruction and fly everywhere. Such bug with pointer type is hard to debug

Author: Aternus#9711
Aternus#9711
Content: @meh would that be correct?

Author: meh#5832
Content: yep :)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
```char *hash;
    char *hash2;```  this declares 2 char pointers.  You can't copy values to them because you've never allocated any space for the actual string that you want them to point to.  You either need to malloc space for them (and then free them later) or use a char array instead.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ``` //hash = crypt(pass, "50");//This doesn't work - strcmp returns 0 always if I use this line```   crypt returns a static pointer to the hashed password.  So that's fine.  `hash` will point to the hash value.  But later on, when you call crypt again, `hash` will now point to the new hash value, as will `hash2`, so strcmp will always return 0, since they both point to the same string.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when you use strcpy, you are copying the actual chars to `hash`, not just pointing hash at that static string.

Author: aw#3567
Content:
Think of variables as little boxes. These boxes can contain what you define them to contain (eg int, char etc).
So defining a variable as char would be akin to having a little box that can only contain a piece of paper with a single character written on it - that is the value assigned to the box/variable. 
Having a char pointer would be defining a box that can only hold a piece of paper that tells you where to look for that characters. I.e. if you open the char pointer box, instead of finding the character (which would be written on the paper as in the case of our char box), you now find a paper that says "go to the room in the South of the house and find the top most paper on the desk"

Author: aw#3567
Content: Where the top most paper on the desk in the room in the South of the house will have the character you are seeking written on it

Author: aw#3567
Content: With hash and hash2, you are basically setting up two boxes, both of which will contain paper detailing the location of where to find the character. But since they are 2 different boxes, &hash and &hash2 will give different results (think of & as asking "where is my box located?"

Author: aw#3567
Content: If the value of pass and str is the same, the crypt function should return the same hash value in both cases. That would be the reason why strcmp returns zero

Author: aw#3567
Content: (typing in a half-asleep state so hopefully that whole chunk made sense.)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Lord of Galaxy#9211 : "//For some reason, hash has the same value as hash2. Does anyone know the reason?"   For the reason I gave before.  crypt returns a pointer to a static character array.  crypt fills that array with the encrypted password.  when you run crypt a second time in the same program, it overwrites/refills that same memory, so anything that was pointing to it now still points to it, but it's the updated string.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Lord of Galaxy#9211 does that make sense?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Lord of Galaxy#9211 there's only one spot in memory for crypt to put the encrypted password, so each time you call it, it reuses that spot.  Your first pointer and your second pointer both point to that same spot.   This is why if you `strcpy` from that spot to a new variable, you keep a "copy" of that string.  If you only set the pointer variable using `hash = ` then you don't.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
why it does it is probably not so important. The problem gives you practice in reading man pages for functions that you might not have used before.  The crypt one has that important line:  ```The returned value points to the  encrypted  password,  a  series  of  13
       printable  ASCII  characters  (the  first  two characters represent the salt itself).  ***The return
       value points to static data whose content is overwritten by each call.***```    That last sentence is the key bit you had missed.

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: To make it a valid string you need to have the array end with a `\0`

Author: Raphael#0843

Author: Aternus#9711
Content:
So to make a string of 5 characters you actually have to write:
```c
char *password[6];
```

and even better, define all the initial values to `\0` so you don't have to worry about `crypt` taking in some `undefined` value that the computer may have in memory when you create the array.
```c
char *password[6] = {};
```

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Recall from the Walkthrough that the main difficulty of this pset is generating the permutations - also note that in this case we are interested in permutations with repetition (where it's possible to have the same letter to appear consecutively)

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: If you take pen and paper and draw a tree for each character, there will be 52 trees

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Each tree has 52 different branches

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: And this happens 5 times

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Which will represent all the possible permutations (with repetition)

Author: Raphael#0843
Content: ok... I think I understand that. But I'm not seeing how I would write that here, maybe I just have to look a bit more into making functions and recursion in c

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: If you can visualize it in the physical world, the pseudo code is quite simple

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Anyway, back to my point...

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: So if you want to get a permutation from your so called garden, you walk to a tree look at it's trunk (the character), then look at the first branch coming out of the trunk, then the branch out of that first branch, etc. until you reach the 5th branch, which should have a leaf (`\0` in our analogy)

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Now as with real trees, there is a possibility that the first branch will have a leaf at it's end and no more branches, so you need to account for that üòâ

Author: Raphael#0843
Content: oohh, ok... I think Im seeing that...

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: If we were to be greedy (as in greedy algorithms) then we would assume that all branches must have other branches, which means we will check from the leaf downwards until we get a match

Author: Aternus#9711
Content:
If we were to be lazy then we would try the shortest possible path for qualification.
If our case the qualification is a match to a sample we already have, i.e. two branches and a leaf, 5 branches and a leaf, etc.

Author: Raphael#0843
Content: then, for each iteration I would do 2 things? one be checking the first character and the following I would account for being a leaf('\0') and the second I would check the first and second character (branches) and then the following Id account for being a leaf, and so on? Maybe Im complicating this

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: There are a number of ways to solve it so you need to try your idea and see where it gets you... if you've hit a dead end, come back to the drawing and start again üòÉ

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: I've solved it naively (doing the `for` loops) but in retrospect it would have been much easier to solve with math

Content: The argument to crypt must be a pointer (a char*) and you're passing it a char.  That's why the compiler is telling you to add the &.  You need to create a string with one character and pass that.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: There many types of dictionary attacks though

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: The most basic is to just hash every single word in the dictionary with no modifications

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Is that what you did?

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Or something else?

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: The next sensible thing to do would be multithreading

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: On Linux it isn't too hard

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: i had to do something else.. just the words in the dictionary isn't enough

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: you have to permute the case of every character in every word in the dictionary

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Yeah, that's there

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: for example above, Lloyd is in the dictionary, but lloyd is not, so that was a permutation of what was in the dictionary

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Though it's most sensible to permute only the first letter

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Any other changes?

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: given the number of trials in brute force, i trialed a different case of every character.

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: because it was still a lot fewer trials than even one brute force iteration through 4 characters.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Yeah

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: But then again, most passwords in the real world have more than just a single simple word

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: there were only ten thousand words in /usr/share/dict/words that matched the constraints of the crypt problem

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: ten thousand is significantly less than (26 * 2) ^ 4

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: actually even 90k less than the number of brute force trials for three characters.

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: and that's considering five trials for every single word in the 10k word dictionary, though I just realized i should have multiplied it by 32

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: since there are 32 variations of 5 characters when you change the case

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Yes

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: So you have a total of 320k trials with dictionary

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: (actually less than that, since some of the words are less than 5 letters)

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Which is considerably lesser than 52^4 {= about 7.3m}

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And definitely less than 52^5

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: just some advice ... this is a "more comfortable" problem, so if you aren't really comfortable already with how chars and strings work, I'd suggest moving on with the lectures and coming back to this problem later.    (I mean this as a general tip, not aimed at you personally) üòÉ

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: char salt[2] will create a char array with 2 characters.  Unless the second character is '\0', it can't be used as a string.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: a string in C is a char array that ends in the null char ('\0')

Author: Mango164#6567
Averax#3343
Content:
If your program is executed without any command-line arguments or with more than one command-line argument, your program should print an error message of your choice (with printf) and return from main a value of 1 (which tends to signify an error) immediately.

From the spec

Author: Mango164#6567
Content:
"and return from main a value of 1 (which tends to signify an error) immediately."
Is it a necessity to include this 1 it for it to signify an error? ("Tends to signify error" What determines whether it does?)
What happens if instead of return 1 it's return 0, or 2, or no return at all?

Author: Averax#3343
Content:
C's main function returns an int... that int goes to the program which executed it (the parent process, if you will) as an exit status code.

Specifically, on most operating systems, a 0 exit code signifies a normal run (no real errors), and non-zero means there was a problem and the program had to exit abnormally.

Author: Mango164#6567
Content:
Wow alright, gotcha!
So would this be the superior, legit, good-design way of representing an error?
Because up to now I thought that I could just represent an error by a print whenever the result of user's input didn't qualify to give the intended type of outcome. But given what you're saying, that's more of like a pseudo-error since the program would technically have run successfully. Am I getting this?

Author: Averax#3343
Content: The value you return can be whatever you want in a normal program. You could then have predefined messages for certain values instead of having to copy and paste that message every time. Eg: An error due to math could return 2 and an error making an array returns 3. By all means do printing but it's also helpful in case there's another program waiting for a 0. But as a standard always use 0 if everything worked üòÉ

Author: Mango164#6567
Content: Alright so it's mostly due to convention of how overarching containers interpret different return values from our programs. Most importantly if it's zero or non-zero. Lastly what determines whether or not I have to use return or not? (Given that plenty of little programs shown in the course so far don't include it)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: The version of C we are using has an implicit `return 0;` so it's not necessary to type it in your code.  You use `return` to end the function immediately.

Author: Mango164#6567
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Keep in mind that a string is a char array that is terminated with a null.  So a string like "a" is stored in memory as `{'a', '\0'}`  You need to have room for that null (and also set it).

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: there is no "string" type in C, which you'll learn in later lectures.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: a "string" is a char array that is terminated with a null char.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so `char array[] = "name"` will declare a "string" that has 5 chars.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `char array[5]` will declare a char array of 5 chars.  If you set the last char to '\0' then you can use it as a string

Author: Ahmad#3683
Content:
Usually the password doesn't store directly in files to check if someone type his password correctly to give him the access to something.

So, it stored as hash word -word that processed using one of hash algorithm-. so, if you type a password. firstly use hash function to find hash word that synonym to your password then compare it with the file.

Author: Ahmad#3683
Content:
Now, you have file that contain hash word. then you should find the word that equal to the password.
Use this fact: the hash function for each password gives uniquely hash value. then compare it with hash values you have.

Author: Grubinski#7755
Content: hi, first your program is just repeating the same action over and over again : i never gets incremented because each time you enter the loop, you call bruteForce() again before the end of the loop and you repeating the same actions again. So i is always the same and you don't change the value of charac either so your program keeps setting pass[0 (i guess] to charset[0].

Author: Grubinski#7755

Author: Randy#3719
Content: usually recursion is decompose a complex problem into a simple problem in order to have better efficiency.

Author: Randy#3719
Content: However, in the brute force approach, the problem is attempt different set of combination, any fork from recursion can directly return a anwser in that specific combination.

Author: Randy#3719
Content: regarding a recursion in a loop, Grubinski had also said that if  a recursion have no terminate condition, will become a inifinite loop.  In addition, a line that calling a function will wait that output return, that bruteForce is almost doing the same thing, and might never get any return value, which also call another type of infinite loop.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
for sure, if you are doing a brute force method to create passwords, the speed differences will come down to the method/order you create the passwords.  Most people seem to test them in a way that starts like: ```a
aa
aaa
aaaa
aaaaa
aaaab
aaaac
aaaad ...``` which means you end up testing a lot of 5-char passwords before you ever test the other 1,2,3,4 ones.  This can be quite slow if the password you are testing is only 2 chars long, for example.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
If you want an easy way to know how long your program takes, you can run it as a `time` argument.  The 'user' time is your program.  So, for example, with the sample "rofl" password given in the spec:  ```
~/workspace/pset2/crack/ $ time ./crack 50fkUxYHbnXGw
rofl

real    0m11.584s
user    0m11.540s
sys     0m0.004s
~/workspace/pset2/crack/ $ ```  It took 11.54 seconds

Author: Daudir#6453
Content: The reason they recommend their IDE 50 cloud environment is that they have control over all the helper libraries that we might need solving the problem sets, that's why some of the psets starts with " first run: update cs50" before doing anything else. Their "make"-program for instance seems to preconfigured somewhat to work out of the box, so that we don't need to use time on debugging anything other than our code. You'll learn some more aspects about "make" in the next pset 'music'. I wouldn't use too much time to get things working offline just yet üòÉ

Author: Calliope37#6158
Content: Hi, I just joined this server and I have a question about this problem set? Here's a photo of my problem:

Author: Calliope37#6158
Content: Apparently crypt("AABA", "12") is different than crypt(current4,"12") even though current4 is literally "AABA"..... Anyone have any idea how this could happen?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: how is `current4` declared?  Does it have the null terminator at the end?

Author: Calliope37#6158
Content: I think so... It's just a string

Author: Calliope37#6158
Content: actually it's a char [4]

Author: Calliope37#6158
Content: Uh here's a link to the code if anyone is still there lol : https://gist.github.com/Calliope37/007dad4b273a19cd083f2b68a72f25e8

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Calliope37 if it's just a char array that hold 4 chars with no ending null terminator, then it's not a proper string, so you'll get unexpected results. (remember, a string is a char array that ends in `'\0'` so the function will keep grabbing chars until it hits the null.  So it's not really "AABA"   it's "AABA plus whatever comes in memory after that until it find a null)

Author: Calliope37#6158
Content: Okay, cool! Thanks for the input. I‚Äôll try adding a null terminal

Content: @mikem17 it's a "more comfortable" (optional) problem designed for students with prior programming experience.  It requires understanding beyond what the course has provided so far.

Author: mikem17#0619
Content: Do you have a suggestion for a resource that might shed some light?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: You basically have to brute force it by creating strings (ie, char arrays that end in null) for all the possible strings up to 5 chars long  (so, "a", "aa", "aaa", ...  "abbbb" ... "zzzzz")  (there are 380 million of them).  As you create them, test them by calling crypt and comparing the output to the hashed password. If it matches, you're done.  You need to understand a bit about how strings work in C (which is covered in future lectures) and how to do loops.

Author: mikem17#0619

Author: Omarrrrrrrrrrr#0939
Content: hey guys, I am getting the following error runtime error: index 1 out of bounds for type 'char [1]'

Author: Omarrrrrrrrrrr#0939
Content: any idea what this is

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: arrays are zero-indexed, so a char array that has only one char can only be accessed with char[0].  You're trying to access char[1] which is beyond the bounds of the array.

Author: Omarrrrrrrrrrr#0939
Content: so for an array that has 0 and 1, I have to call it array [2]

Author: Omarrrrrrrrrrr#0939
Content: I mean the program works, and I get the characters I copied to the array, but I get this error even though the program finishes running anyway

Author: Omarrrrrrrrrrr#0939
Content: it makes no sense

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you want an array that can hold 2 chars, you have to declare it as `char array[2];`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and then you access each char with `array[0]` and `array[1]`

Author: Bogdan#6418
Content: https://pastebin.com/tFfRC8FF

Author: Bogdan#6418
Content: I have a problem

Author: Bogdan#6418
Content: On line 80

Author: Bogdan#6418
Content: Can you help?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Bogdan your overall issue is that you haven't null-terminated *any* of your strings (your salt and your test strings).  A string is a char array that ends in the null char `'\0'`  Any function that takes a string will read the bytes from the start of the array until it hits a null, so if you haven't specifically set that value (and left room for it when you declared your array), you will get unexpected results.

Author: Bogdan#6418
Content: Oh ok thanks

Author: Bogdan#6418
Content: Does it works when I compare strings?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: strcmp is expecting strings (ie char arrays that are null-terminated).  It will keep comparing each character until it hits a null.

Author: hateiskawaii#2069
Content: A brute force crack algorithm for any password regardless of encryption type has two properties

Author: hateiskawaii#2069
Content: 1. It will *always* be successful (by successful here I mean possible)

Author: hateiskawaii#2069
Content: 2. It will take an exorbitant amount of computational resources (time)

Author: hateiskawaii#2069
Content: It is not that hard to make a password (even using older encryption types like DES) that would be impossible for someone to break in this way *before the Universe ends*

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: Do I understand correctly that if I use the 'time' command, 'user' is the relevant time to measure how quick my program is rather than 'real'?

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: Or is it 'user' plus 'sys'?

Author: Gigolas#6655
Content: @thorndeux real is the answer.

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: Hmm, so what accounts for the discrepancy between  CPU-times ('user' and 'sys') and 'real' time? Accessing memory?

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/556405/what-do-real-user-and-sys-mean-in-the-output-of-time1

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Real is human experienced time, user and sys are time the CPU actually spends on the actual process (so without interruption or blocking)

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: The difference between user and sys seems subtle : one is time spend inside the kernel (sys) and the other outside (user)

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Time actually spend by the CPU should be user + sys

Content: I asked here because I noticed that 'real' time was different when I called the same program with the same parameter at different times

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: So I suspected that, because our IDE is running in a virtual machine on a server, probably the CPU running our program was just busier with other stuff sometimes

Author: Gigolas#6655
Content: what about user stats? were they same?

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: yes, more or less

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: but the real time would be 0.35 vs 1.45 or sth like that

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: so more than a second difference for the exact same thing

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: which can only be explained by factors outside the program itself

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: If you look at the top answer in the link https://stackoverflow.com/questions/556405/what-do-real-user-and-sys-mean-in-the-output-of-time1

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: It says this about 'real' time: "Real is wall clock time - time from start to finish of the call. This is all elapsed time including time slices used by other processes and time the process spends blocked (for example if it is waiting for I/O to complete)."

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: There is no relevant I/O time in crack, only one printf at the very end

Author: thorndeux#8839
Content: So the difference between user time and real time must come from other, unrelated processes, as I understand it

Content: From a readability perspective

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Even if the underlying workings make it work

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Quite the contrary. The old example I saw of using crypt just used the entire hash as the salt. In fact, I'm pretty sure it is by design

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Besides, it simplifies everything

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: After all, if the actual hash output of the function contains the salt, there must be a reason for that.

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Considering the crypt function probably wasn't designed with cracking passwords as a pset in mind, in the normal case you wouldn't have the entire hash at your disposal. The fact that it works seems to me like a side effect of the way the function treats with pointers.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: What?

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Of course you would have the entire hash at your disposal

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: You need the hash to verify if the password is correct or not

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Otherwise what's the whole point of a password

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: (honestly though, there's no _real_ point to supporting DES in the first place as its not the best thing in the world - you want _at least_ MD5)

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Yes you get the hash out of the function

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Your not supposed to have it prior to using the function

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: That's why I say the function wasn't designed with passing the whole hash to it in mind

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Using passwords is a two step process

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: First, you get a password from the user

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Then you hash it (because you _never_ store passwords as plain text) with a fairly random salt, and store it

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Then, when the user tries to "log in" (or whatever), and inputs their password again, you hash their input _again_, using the same salt as when you encrypted it, and compare this new hash with the stored hash. If the hashes match, then the password is correct

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: That's why you must have access to the complete hash

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: You've got a point

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: But I thought the salts were sometimes generated randomly so even the same password gives out two different hashes. I don't get what's the point of randomizing the salt if the complete hash is used to verify if the password is correct ? It's a genuine question, maybe I missed something ü§î

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Oh

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: The point of the salt is this

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Imagine two users use the same password

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: What using a salt does is to make sure that the hashes of the passwords of the two users are different

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: If someone manages to get access to the hashes, they wouldn't be able to tell that the two users had the same password

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: Oh that makes sense

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: So it's not about safety against ¬´cracking¬ª attempts but more about the database being compromised ?

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Yeah

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Though it does provide safety against cracking too, in a way

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: If someone cracks a particular hash with a particular salt, they still need to do the same for every other salt

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Otherwise they only really find out one person's password

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: If A and B have same password, but the alt used for both differs, then a hacker wouldn't find out B's password just by cracking A's password

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: He would need to crack both A's and B's password separately

Author: NAmbry#2791
Content: I see, makes sense üòÄ

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content:
For example, "password" encrypted with the salt of 50 gives:
```
50q.zrL5e0Sak
```

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content:
While the same hashed with the salt 51 gives:
```
51CbcBM13fOMo
```

Content: also, if `ptr` is a `char *`, then `ptr` is how you use the string in `printf`

Author: asinfinity09#2610

Author: asinfinity09#2610
Content: @@Lord of Galaxy  ThanksüòÄ

Author: asinfinity09#2610
Content:
How does placing the #define term any where else other than the very top affect.
I just need the reason.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: In short, it's a feature test macro

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: In particular, a lot of things are done in the header `features.h`

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: (or maybe `fearure.h`)

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: (it may be named differently for different platforms, or even just different compilers, not sure)

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: `string.h` includes `features.h` (I checked source, but I could have checked some wrong version)

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And at that point, `_XOPEN_SOURCE` is not defined

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: As a result, `features.h` sets some other macros

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Subsequent inclusions of `features.h` are ignored

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: As a result, the macros defined are defined without `_XOPEN_SOURCE` in mind

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And when `unistd.h` sees this, it decides you're in the wrong environment, and fails to define `crypt`

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: BTW technically those aren't exactly compile errors, just warnings

Author: von Ang#4889
Content:
Hey there,
I have the error:

```crack.c:35:19: error: implicit declaration of function 'crypt' is invalid in C99 [-Werror,-Wimplicit-function-declaration]   if(strcmp(crypt(password, salt), hash))             ^
crack.c:35:19: error: incompatible integer to pointer conversion passing 'int' to parameter of type 'const char *' [-Werror,-Wint-conversion]   if(strcmp(crypt(password, salt), hash))
^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

You seem to have an error in crack.c on line 35. By "implicit declaration of function 'crypt'", clang means that it doesn't recognize crypt. Did you forget to #include <unistd.h>
(in which crypt is declared) atop your file? Do you have #define _XOPEN_SOURCE above, not below, #include <unistd.h>?```

Author: von Ang#4889
Content:
At least for me, that did not help. I don't know if this is considered a spoiler, but "the trick" for me was realizing that the salt is saved with the password. So the computer knows what hash was used when you first created your password. If your password is "hunter2" it would be hashed with a random salt like "9a". The hash is created with "9ahunter2". So another user with this awesome password would get another random salt like "zG", so the hash is created with "zGhunter2". If you just look at the password file, you would not know that this user has the same password as you. Also if a hacker has access to the password file she cannot just search for all standard password pre-hashed, as it is always hashed with a random salt. That makes it harder for the hacker, or at least it takes longer. 

If you log in a second time with your hunter2 password, a new hash is created and checked with the saved hash. It has to be the same to let you through. So the same salt has to be used. This is why the original salt is saved together with the password. So every login attempt can be hashed with the same salt that was originally created.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: That's not a 'trick'...

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: It's all in the man pages

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And DES does _not_ make the random salt for you

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: You have to give it a random salt when _encrypting_, i.e. when hashing a new password to be stored

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: In this case, you already have the hash

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: The man pages clearly mention that the first two characters are the salt

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: (at least in DES mode)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `string salt = "!!";`  this declares a "string literal" which is stored in read-only memory.  If you try to change its value, you will segfault since you are touching memory that you don't have access to.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you want a new string, declare a char array that can hold 2 chars + the null char at the end.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: password[]  = "Georg"  creates a 6 byte null-terminated char array  `'G' 'e' 'o' 'r' 'g' '\0'`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: your way creates a 5 byte char array  (which cannot be used as a string in other functions expecting a string)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: a string is a null-terminated char array

Author: VangelisAndr#6126
Content: If I added the: passwprd[5] = '\0'; would that make it a 6 byte null-terminated char array?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you don't have a null at the end, the function will keep reading memory until it finds one, and then treat *that* as the string.

Author: Ellie#5292
Content: not sure the difference between real, user and sys.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Real is the actual time taken, what you'd measure on your wall clock

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: User is the _CPU time taken_ when in ***USER*** mode

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Sys is the _CPU time taken_ when in ***SYSTEM*** mode

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: (System mode is when it's in the kernel rather than when running normal user library code)

Author: Ellie#5292
Content: Yeah I could guessed that but I'm not sure which should I be looking at  for comparison. Thanks.

Content: I'd suppose the sum of `user` and `sum`

UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer:DEADLYSIGNAL

    #0 0x42808e in main /root/sandbox/crack.c:16:17
    #1 0x7fb555777b96 in __libc_start_main /build/glibc-OTsEL5/glibc-2.27/csu/../csu/libc-start.c:310

Content: this is the main code

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891

Content: and i have defined it

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so that's a segmentation fault (you are trying to write to memory you don't have access to).  what is line 16?

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: salt[0]

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I'm guessing it's where you write to `salt[0]`?   You've declared `string salt = "aA";`  which is a string literal (string literals are stored in read-only memory and cannot be altered)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you should declare it as a char array instead.  `char salt[] = "aA";` would work

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: oh

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: wait doesnt arrays need you to define each one

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: if i were to just do char salt[1] would that work just as well?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: that is defining it.  `char salt[] = "aA";` is the same as `char salt[3] = {'a', 'A', '\0'};`

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: ah

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: the box can be empty?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it can be empty if you are initializing the array with a value.  The compiler knows how many chars to allocate to it based on the initialized value.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you can't just say `char salt[]`; because that doesn't have any known size.

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: okay then

Author: ZeloAvarosa#6891
Content: im gonna make a note of that

Content: Yeah when you think about how the program parts are linked, saying "compare i to (value)" versus "compare i to (return the length of some char array)" really does make a difference on something like a brute-force problem

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: That's too big a difference, and specific names don't matter

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: What really matters is average time for actually decent passwords

Author: Midge#3751
Content: Well how else would you benchmark performance if you didn't compare using the same names? I see where you're getting at I think, in that your program might just be solving one specific one fast incidentally, but considering more of a generic dev approach, you'd test against the same suite of passwords with each attempted optimization. So they do matter.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: You'd test with a sufficiently large list of passwords as opposed to a single one

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: A matter of miscommunication

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: When I said specific names don't matter I meant any one single password doesn't matter

Author: Saturnalia#8975

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You can flatten the loops to one, allowing easy extension to longer passwords, but time complexity remains, unless you find a better algorithm, e.g. using rainbow tables (salt is small with that one)

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Dictionary attacks

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: That's the way

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: For this particular problem, no heuristics needed either

Author: phantomware#8056

Author: phantomware#8056

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you aren't given the password. The idea is that your crack program will actually return something given the hash.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
it's a more comfortable problem. You can solve it in whatever way you want. The simplest is using brute force, but as the spec says:    "Recall that sometimes, people use passwords that are actual words. Perhaps there‚Äôs an optimization that can be employed?
Brute force algorithms aren‚Äôt the fastest, and that‚Äôs okay! Recall that shorter passwords are usually easier to crack than longer ones."

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
the spec also gives you this:  ```$ ./crack
Usage: ./crack hash
$ ./crack 50cI2vYkF0YU2
LOL```  so you have at least one example where you are given the password.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: You could also encrypt your own examples and then try to crack them

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: here's a short little program I wrote that gives you the hash when you give it a password  https://github.com/curiouskiwi/cs50x-help/blob/master/crypt.c

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: your program only needs to take a hash and return a password.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: as a More Comfortable problem, you aren't necessarily expected to solve this with what's been taught so far.

Content: here is my psuedocode for the assignment. i just wanted to make sure that i have a basic understanding of what to do. am i missing any big steps? am i even on the right track?

Author: Kyruel#7810
Content:
`accept one command line arguement which is a hashed password
create a string with the first two variables of the hashed password as the salt
create a loop that goes over all possible alphanumerics and adds them to the string with the 2 letter salt
nest an additional 4 loops inside each other that do the same thing since it can only be up to 5 characters
the additional loops should also loop over " " so it can locate shorter passwords
hash each attempt with the specified salt and compare it to arg[1]
when arg[1] == the string_compare of the string i created earlier then print the alphanumeric version of the string`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
>create a loop that goes over all possible alphanumerics and adds them to the string with the 2 letter salt

not sure what you mean by "adds them to the string with the salt".   The passwords you are creating/checking don't have the salt added to them.  If the password is "apple", then you'd hash it using the salt from the hash you are testing, and compare the result to the hash.

Author: Papounet94#9051
Content: I used a different approach. I have a single loop from 0

Author: Papounet94#9051
Content: to  62^(the number of letters of the password)

Author: Papounet94#9051
Content: 62 = 26+26+10 for uppercase and lowercase letters + numbers.

Author: Papounet94#9051
Content: Then, knowing the number N of letters of the password I am looking for, I generate N indexes for every letter of the password, each being incremented differently.

Author: Papounet94#9051
Content: I used a lot of %62 in the process !

Author: Papounet94#9051
Content: Hope this helps.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: calling crypt is what takes the time, so the better algorithm will reduce the average number of calls to crypt.  Maybe there's a better order to create the possible passwords.

Author: AriAsiaN#6921
Content: I managed to do just that, with my previous code the longest hash took 17 minutes to crack, but now after making some changes and reducing the call to crypt , the longest time to crack (among the specification hashes) is 11 minutes. malan's hash was cracked in 2 minutes, but with the changes I made, now bjbrown's hash takes the longest (11 min) to crack.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: @curiouskiwi hmm that's right... But a dictionary attack is kinda just that, and I wanted to avoid that

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Lord of Galaxy I wasn't talking about a dictionary attack.  I was referring to the order of the words that you are 'creating' to be tested.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content:
@curiouskiwi indeed, but that won't work if the passwords were all truly random - if they were random, the average time would remain the same
Which means any improvement that relies on the order in which the passwords are 'created' is only looking for some kind of pattern - heuristics - in the passwords

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Which, in a way, is closely related to how dictionary attacks work

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yep, I take your point.

Author: armchair#4520
Content:
Is this reasoning correct? Just to make sure I fully understand the crypt function

crypt hashes a password (key) along with a salt (2 randomly chosen characters) and the output is a hash. The first two characters of this hash represent the salt that was initially used to hash the password in the first place.

Author: armchair#4520
Content:
If this is correct, then how does the computer arrive at the same hash when you try to login as the salt is always randomly chosen?

1. When you register your password the first time: hash based on key + random salt gets stored somehwere on computer
2. When you log on and type in a password, computer hashes the password again with a random salt but still arrives at same hash that was calculated in step 1

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @armchair the salt is not random.  If you call `crypt("LOL", "50");` then you'll get a hash value using "50" as the salt.  That hash value will start with "50".  That's the number stored.  Now when the person logs in, you use the same salt to encrypt the password entered, and then compare.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: The salt may be originally random when chosen but going forward you use the same one.

Author: armchair#4520
Content: So then the computer just checks the first 2 chars of the stored hash and uses that as salt when user logs back in?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yes

Content: every potential password you create has been malloced and never freed, so I'm not surprised you run into memory issues.  Not sure why you use malloc at all, rather than just a char array.  It will be a lot slower using malloc too.

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: I tried to do that but ran into an issue calling the variable I needed to free because it didn't exist outside the function.  I guess I could have made a variable to use before I called the function?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yes, and pass that to the function.  (or don't use malloc)

Content: does anyone have any idea why crypt() keeps returning the same string despite being fed different arguments each loop?

Author: Dornyel#3652
Content: example

Content: printing out the password in the same scope shows that it is being changed each iteration

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: pay close attention to the description of crypt in the man page

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
esp this part:  "The  returned  value
       points to the encrypted password, a series of 13
       printable ASCII characters (the first two  char‚Äê
       acters  represent  the salt itself).  The return
       value points to static  data  whose  content  is
       overwritten by each call."

Author: Dornyel#3652
Content: static data whose content is overwritten by each call

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so are you trying to store the crypt value and then print it after you've already called crypt again?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it's unclear from your screenshot what the timing is

Author: Dornyel#3652
Content: so each iteration i change the guessed password, store the crypt value, then print it

Author: Dornyel#3652
Content: in that order

Author: Dornyel#3652

Author: Dornyel#3652
Content: might it be because my password variable is a char array without a null value at the end?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: crypt is expecting a null-terminated array ... it will send as many chars as it has until it hits a null.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: remember, a "string" is always null terminated, otherwise it's just a char array.

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: Can someone explain why this would work for a string created with get_string() but not when the string is just declared?

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: `pw[i] = alpha[j];`

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: If I use get_string() and type in AAAAA

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: The program runs as intended

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: if I declare `string pw = "AAAAA";`, though, I get an `UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer:DEADLYSIGNAL`

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: Why would that be?

Author: dpkonofa#8575
Content: literally the only difference is my code is `string pw = get_string("Password: ");` vs `string pw = "AAAAA";`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and those are entirely different things.  `string pw = "AAAAA";` declares an immutable (read only) string  (ie, a string literal")   `pw = get_string()` declares a pointer called pw that points to space that has been allocated on the heap for a char array  (all of this is explained in week 3 and 4).  For now, you should declare your 'string' as a char array that is null terminated, so it can be used in functions expecting a string.

Author: Doge#9515
Content: `char pass[] = "LOL";` pass is a 4 member array containing L O L \0, in your `pass[3]` you should add a null terminator (\0), so you have `char pass[4]` @0x4E696E6A75

Author: Doge#9515
Content: without the null you pass a random trash value into crypt that begins with LOL and that's why your program always outputs a different result, your input is always different.

Author: Key#3708
Content: So I want to try this project but ... I am clueless? What I'm understanding from the instructions is that all I have to do is give an argument at the command line for the program to spit out a password for me. So why do I need crypt? My understanding of crypt is that it encrypts passwords

Author: TotalJustice#9179
Content: You use crypt to encrypt every password combination until it creates a hash that‚Äôs identical to the one you entered at the command line, if it matches the hash, the password is correct

Author: TotalJustice#9179
Content: And your task is basically figuring out how crypt works, find a way to check each possible combination (follow the spec for what you should check) and then compare the hash against the one from command line @Key

Author: Lotus#7714
Content: Is there a list with the actual decrypted passwords we can check against?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
You can make your own. Either you call `crypt` with a known string, and let it print the result, or you use an online DES hash generator.
Some of the provided passwords are just two characters, I just don't know which ones. If you go breadth-first, not depth-first, you should find the shorter ones within seconds.

Author: Ooftop09#6709
Content: The difference between multithreading vs single thread is amazing at 5 char passwords üòÄ it's slower at < 4 because of additional error checking, was fun as hell to optimize this problem. Not to mention I learned a bunch about posix threads

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: That's the point of the hash function, it's meant to be unfeasible to brute-force passwords. And a few decades ago, with this algorithm, it likely was.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: My university, about 15 years ago, introduced a new NFC smart card based on "mifare classic". The argument was that the encryption happens on the card, and brute-force attacks won't profit from more compute power outside the card. Well, there were more flaws. But I don't think anybody cares as long as nobody abuses the system (e.g. clones keys via replay attacks).

Content: So I‚Äôve run into an issue I can‚Äôt wrap my head around. To help me better understand filling the guess array with all possible alphabetical values I‚Äôve put a blank array of [3] on a sheet of paper and cut up little squares of ABC\0 to fill them. If I use the null character to increment the the guess array like an odometer I‚Äôll inevitably land on a situation where I pass ‚Äò\0 A‚Äô  to the crypt() function. Will crypt error because of this? Whereas if I try to put a safeguard like placing an if (null) condition before the crypt function I couldn‚Äôt have arrays of only one character in length. Unless I could make the array grow from 1 units long to 3 as if guess[1] and guess[2] only come into existence when a value is placed inside them. Is that even possible? What am I missing here? If I use the last letter to increment the problem goes away, but a different one arises where ‚ÄòAC‚Äô becomes ‚ÄòBAA‚Äô instead of ‚ÄòBC‚Äô. Please help. I‚Äôm 3 days into crack and my brain is liquefying.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: in your 3 char example (with strings either 1 or 2 chars long), if you start with char word[3] = { `'\0', '\0', '\0'` }  (ie, all nulls)  then increment word[0] with 'A', then that's the string "A".   Eventually, you'll get to 'z', '\0', '\0'  and then you increment word[0] back to 'A', and start changing word[1], so you have 'A', 'A', '\0'  (ie, "AA") and then "AB" ... etc.

Content: Thanks for hoping in kiwi. crack is making a fool of me! This feels like what I've been doing, but I do notice a subtle difference. I'm going to take a few minutes work through it and if I'm still seeing a logical error hopefully i can better understand or explain where im going wrong.

Author: WayneTheBrain#2337
Content: You saved my life kiwi. Filling in 'A' 'A' --> 'A' 'B' instead of 'A' 'A' --> 'B' 'A' made all the difference. Sweet relief

Author: WayneTheBrain#2337
Content: Thank you!

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: In one of my versions, I always incremented first character, and if that passed the range of valid characters, would reset it and increment the next, similar to add-with-carry with a kind of reversed number (least significant "digit" first). Any direction can work, as long as `'\0'` comes last.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Depends on how you wrote it. Usually short keywords should be found earlier (you can hash a word yourself for testing). If you however are doing depth first (all words of any length starting with A, then all words starting with B, ...), you might want to limit the maximum password length while testing. If you did breadth first (1-letter keywords, 2-letter keywords, ...), a short word should be found earlier.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Most mistakes affecting longer passwords should show up in 2 or 3 character passwords.

Content: It's a factor of 52 for each additional character. And a part of that process is spent in `crypt`, and unless you are hashing same passwords twice, there's no way to speed up that part.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you don't add the null char, then `salt` cannot be reliably used as a string, because a string is a char array ending in null.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: instead, whatever function is trying to use it will keep reading chars until it finds a null, which may be some bytes further along in memory that you don't control.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
My approach in one implementation was to increment the first character, and if that flowed over, I would reset it to the first character and increment the second, and so on, until I would reach a character that does not overflow, or word end. If the last character overflowed, I'd increase the length of the password and set the new last character to the first character of my alphabet.
I used a separate array for the indices (that's where I would increment), a hard-coded string as an alphabet, and an array for the actual password (initialised to all zeroes, and changed whenever I update an index).

My first solution would use recursion instead, and was much slower because of the overhead of all those function calls.

Author: VangelisAndr#6126
Content:
Kazun you can try first by printing one character, char1 from a to z. Once oyu do this then try adding another character char2 right next to char1 and print that one as well from a to z together. Once you get this right then you understand the basic concept and all you need to do is replicate this model until you have 4 characters in a row. Then you can re-adjust the print function to any other function you want to return or try the number against the hash etc.

I find very useful to break the problem down into small tasks and even these tasks into even simpler more primitive tasks until I get the concepts step by step and then grow from there

Actually, I remembered what was the problem exactly.
I was able to exit the recursive func itself, but it was wrapped inside a for loop in an outer function, and I needed to break out of this outer loop on the exit condition of the recursive func.

If the recursive func exits successfully, the loop continues invoking that function unless there's a global variable check (that's being set with the successful exit). And I can't simply return a success code and check if it's true to break out of the outer loop.

I'll play around more with it later, but I can't figure out how to refactor it.
For now, I'm just happy it's finally works üòÑ

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: I realize now that this is the wrong way to go about getting the hash value from the command line as the hash will be the entire string, but in the interest of understanding I'm asking this anyways. Why am I getting this error? I malloc an array of chars big enough to store the hash and then write it in one character at a time. At the end I free the memory. I feel like I'm missing something obvious.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: hash++ is moving the address stored in hash, so when you try to free it, it's pointing to memory that wasn't what was malloced.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: also, you `if not argv[1] or argv[2]`  isn't checking what you think.   if you are trying to make sure the user entered a hashvalue, you should check that argc is 2.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: (well, I suppose that does the same thing .. it's just an odd way to do it.   `argc` exists specifically for that purpose)

Author: noob4ever#1127
Content: @curiouskiwi  Thank you for that.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @noob4ever thirdly, if you are creating a string, be sure that you null terminate it (and that you have declared it with enough space to hold that null char)  a string like "50" requires 3 chars of space.

Author: allsunday#1958
Content: memcpy is a function in string.h

Author: allsunday#1958
Content: memcpy(dest, src, n) will take n bytes from src and copy them in dest

Author: allsunday#1958
Content: dest and src ar pointers, and they're closely related to arrays. The thing is, if you do something like ``char dest[3]`` before calling memcpy, you'll have an array where you can store those chars. You want that to be a string so find a way for dest[2] to be '\0'

Author: allsunday#1958
Content: and remember that, like you said, every char is 8 bits = 1 byte, and n is the number of bytes to be copied

Content: that's how I did it because I didn't want to take those first chars by hand, but you can do it that way too of course

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: that's a "string literal", which means the expectation is that the value will never change, so it's stored in memory that is immutable (can't be changed)

       string i_str = get_string("l:")

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: that is a string that is stored  in heap memory and is therefore mutable.

Content:
just ran a small test.  I printed each word (33178 attempts) and my program took   ```

real    0m6.153s
user    0m0.100s
sys     0m0.080s``` and then I recompiled without the printf
```
~/pset2/ $ time ./crack 50PaJ4.RO0YUo
cracked with 33178 attempts: abc

real    0m0.202s
user    0m0.094s
sys     0m0.000s
```   so you can see  over 6 seconds versus 2/10th of a second.

Author: hi im steven#6206
Content: well this case is actually not base 52, it's base 53 because you have to include a null character sort of, but we dont count those possibilities so the total possibilities in N characters can only be found by 52^5 + 52^4 + 52^3 + 52^2 + 51^1 + 52^0 = 387659012 which is nowhere near 52^6

Author: thebluestfox#9307
Content:
Hey guys,

Just finished the crack assignment from Problem Set 2.
However I feel like my code could be better, seeing as it is quite repetitive with regards to iterating over different password lengths. I keep thinking that perhaps there's a way to this with a custom function?
Also I vaguely remember David saying something about a rule of thumb that the maximum amount of nested for loops should rarely exceed 3. I have 5 nested for loops in the section of my program where it checks for a match for a 5 letter password.
Also any other thoughts or suggestions would be much appreciated.
Here's my source code:
https://gist.github.com/thebluestfox/d1c051ce5f6a518294f668a7c2dbc920

Author: AFRS#7371
Content: Hi , my english not very good can explain what is crypt algorithm ü§î

Author: DRL#1287
Content: @thebluestfox I think I got around having multiple sets of loops (as in not having 2 nested loops followed by 3 nested loops followed by 4 etc.) by including the null character `\0` in my cycle of characters

Author: DRL#1287
Content: this way the string is cut off early during some of the guesses, thus it only takes one set of loops (5 nested)

Author: DRL#1287
Content: The issue is, I think, that the code is *technically* cleaner, but it might take longer to execute because I'm wasting cpu cycles assigning values to indexes after the `\0`

Author: DRL#1287
Content: So in the case of a program like this, I think yours is actually better where execution time matters way more than "code cleanliness"

Author: DRL#1287
Sanath#7244
Content: Pretty much

Author: thebluestfox#9307
Content: @DRL yeah, the runtime doesn't seem bad

Author: DRL#1287
Content:
Yeah, it's honestly probably better to do it your way to keep it as fast as possible. In mine you'll run into situations where the string looks like this:

[A] [A] [NULL] [B] [B]

Author: forg#9122
Content: Hi - I am so so confused on how crypt() operates. I've been playing with it in the IDE to work up crack.c - to follow my code I've put some printf()s in and am using "50" as the salt and "B" as the key. If I run crypt using these parameters in the scope of main(), I return a hash 50awdcPOdlHdE and I've saved that to a char *hashTwo. Now, if I run crypt using the same 50 / B parameters (stored in new variables) within a for loop, the crypt hash is instead 50Sx5GEnnqonc. Following debug50 I can see the value at hashTwo has changed from 50awd... to 50Sx5... I assume this is because crypt() stores the hash in a memory location and the output variable pointer simply points to that char *, so any other pointers would see their value change. However, I am super confused about why the hash outcome is different when the key and the salt are the same.

Author: forg#9122
Content: In another test, I added another crypt(50,B) lower in my main() code and this time the outer hash (that was 50awdcPOdlHdE  before) is 50DesJI0pV2ls for BOTH crypt()s in main() and the crypt() within the for loop still returns 50Sx5GEnnqonc as I did not add a new crypt(50,B) function.

Author: forg#9122
Content: How can the hashing be inconsistent considering equal parameters?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you pass the same strings, it will give the same output.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: crypt("B", "50")  will return 506AM4LYuoGsQ

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Are you sure that you are passing "B" as the password?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @forg

Author: forg#9122
Content: Yep - all instances take the same parameters. If you want to see the code I'm using, I can share the file with you in CS50 IDE - dm me your IDE username

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I just saw your reddit post.  You aren't passing it the string "B".  You are passing it a single char 'B'

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so crypt is going to go to the address in memory where your 'B' is stored, and grab the string it finds there (ie, starting at that address and grabbing each byte until it hits the NUL char)

Author: forg#9122
Content: Yea, I was working on understanding it from the ground up so I started with a single char. Is that bad?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: crypt needs a string

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ie, a properly terminated array of characters

Author: forg#9122
Content: Ah - I see. So the hash isn't actually for "B" it's for B + garbage because there's no null terminator

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: right

Author: forg#9122
Content: So, in memory, are the two Bs outside the for loop the same? Because the hashTwo and hashThree are always the same in my tests. That would make me think the char acts as a pointer, whereas I though when a char variable was initialized and declared to be 'b', it was it's own point in local memory and separate from other variables, even if they carried the same value.

Author: forg#9122
Content: Then, the 'b' within the for loop is it's own scope so different memory. Or am I confusing what is going on

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
forg#9122
Content: Yea, when that is uncommented the hash is the same. Which, if it were null terminated is what we'd expect considering the salt is the same, right? But if there is garbage after then crypt() could be run on just about anything so we'd expect the hash to be different if the char variables are followed by different garbage.

Author: forg#9122
Content: I guess I'm confused about the fact that adding hashThree changes hashTwo. I follow you that a char is not null terminated but I guess now my misunderstanding is about how memory works.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
well, here goes.   When the compiler compiles, it pushes the different variables onto the stack memory.  In the case of your program, before it makes the function call to crypt, it has to put the parameters onto the stack.  So it puts the address of the string literal "50" (ie, your salt) onto the stack and it puts 'B' (your xTwo) onto the stack.  In memory, those are stored consecutively.  So crypt runs and it uses for the password 'B' + the actual address of "50" 

When you call then declare saltThree to "50", because it's the same string literal, the compiler treats it as the same as saltTwo so it only has the same address.   It puts that address onto the stack and  then puts xThree 'B' onto the stack.  Now crypt is called again.

Because the unterminated 'B' is followed in memory by that same salt address, you get the same garbage string.

In your for loop, that's in a different spot in memory, so you don't.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @forg

Author: forg#9122
Content: Ok, thank you. So, xThree is indeed in a new memory location on the stack. But, the compiler determines that there are two identical string literals (saltTwo and saltThree) and assigns them the same memory address, I assume for efficiency? If I were to later change saltTwo or saltThree (or any two identical string literals), then, I should be aware of the fact that changing one will change both, so should do so via strcpy(). Does my understanding sound in line?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: You can't change a string literal.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
When I run that program I see this:  ```
hashTwo: 50zuL7kUzL3WI
hashThree: 50zuL7kUzL3WI
Here's the address of saltTwo: 0x400834
Here's the memory from xTwo and following 11 bytes:
42 34 8 40 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 
Here's the address of saltThree: 0x400834
Here's the memory from xThree and following 11 bytes:
42 34 8 40 0 0 0 0 0 0 42 2b 
```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you can change what the char* points to, but not the actual string literal.

Author: forg#9122
Content: Thanks! Seeing what the memory address is laid out in front of me was super helpful!

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so you can later say `saltThree = "75";`  and that wouldn't affect `saltTwo`

Content: a string is a char array that ends in the NUL char.  So if you have an array like `char name[5];` that can hold any string up to 4 characters long.  so if you set `name[0] = 'A'` and `name[1] = '\0'` , then that's the string `"A"`    is that what you mean?

Content: the issue is that `string out = "\0";` declares what is called in C a "string literal".

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: those are stored in read-only memory

Author: curiouskiwi#1671

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Ali Hasan essentially, crypt takes a string like "mypassword" and when given a "salt" (which is a 2 character string like "50") it will return an encrypted string.  It is meant to be a one-way encryption, such that with the encrypted string, you cannot get back to the plain text.   Your goal in this problem is to try to decrypt the encrypted string, by trying all possible combinations of up to 5 character strings, encrypting each with the same salt, and comparing the result to your encrypted string to see if it matches.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: how is `a` declared?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you have `char a[6];`  that will declare an array that can hold up to a 5 character string.  but in order for it to be treated as a string, the last letter must be followed by the nul char '\0'.  so if you set `a[0] = 'a'` and` a[1] = '\0'`, that can be treated as the string `"a"`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you want a string "aa", then you'd set a[0] to 'a', a[1] to 'a' and a[2] to '\0'

Author: Ali Hasan#0945
Content: char a[2] = 'a' isn't it supposed to put NULL automatically ?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it's an array, so there's no requirement for there to be a NUL.  If you want a NUL, you have to put one.

Author: Ali Hasan#0945
Content: are u sure of this ? everywhere i read it says it adds the NULL automatically at the end

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Yes, I am sure.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you declare `char name[6];` and then set name[0] to 'H', nothing is going to automatically put a nul char in position1 in the array.  You may be lucky in that the memory allocated to you for your array happens to have null in it, but that's just luck.

Author: Ali Hasan#0945
Content: and what happens if i didn't add that null ?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: any function that is using that as a string will keep reading in memory until it finds a null, and use that as the end of string marker.

Author: Ali Hasan#0945
Content: got it !

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so you'll get garbage in your string

Author: Ali Hasan#0945

Author: curiouskiwi#1671

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you say `char a[2]  = "a";`  you are initializing `a` with the characters 'a' and '\0'   so in that case, it *is* putting the  nul char for you.   That's a special initialization feature.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but that only happens when you *declare* and *initialize* in one step.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if you said `char a[2];` to declare an array with 2 chars, you can't later say `a[2] = "a";` because at that point `a[2]` isn't even part of `a` since `a` will only have `a[0]` and `a[1]`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: In my example, I was declaring `char a[6];`  and then, setting a[0] to 'a' and a[1] to '\0', so if I then tried to printf %s of a, I'd get "a" since it's a char array that has a NUL char.

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content:
@risen_hate / soangrypanda I saw it like this: when a string is "increased", there is a "wave" of increment moving from one end. Often it stops immediately, at the ending character, because it was not the last in the alphabet. Sometimes all the alternatives for the ending character are already used and the wave moves to the next (second to last) character in a row, while the ending character is reset. But then this second character gets the same treatment as the ending character on the previous step: it is either replaced with the next in the alphabet or reset to a with the wave moving on.
So instead of as many nesting cycles as the characters in the string, there can be two cycles, the outer cycle implementing the brute force search itself and the inner cycle implementing this wave replacing one character in the string and deciding if it will go to the next character or stop here.

Author: kadavraverkisto#7943
Content: (But my version of the algorithm was probably rather clumsy anyway)
